body:
We're using the [url crate](https://docs.rs/url/1.7.1/url/) to validate if what has been clicked on is a valid URL. And it seems to report that it indeed is a valid URL. Looking at stuff like `about:config`, I'd assume that this is not a bug in the URL crate, but that this is indeed a valid URL.

It has been mentioned in a different issue, but maybe we should be more restrictive? My initial idea was to make as much valid stuff clickable as possible, but that could be reevaluated. Maybe a fixed set of protocols should be selected? That certainly would introduce the danger of breaking some usecases though.

So `std::marker` should be a valid IPv6 url, but I think `std::marker::Send` is not, because having two `::` makes their positioning unclear. I'll see if I can open a bug for the crate, though it won't fix all the false positives it should help with some.

issue.title: Add test case for ambiguous ipv6
issue.body: I don't think this should be merged, because CI will fail, but it would be nice to start the conversation if this truly should be an error. Motivation is reducing false positives in https://github.com/jwilm/alacritty/issues/1727 . If we determine it should be an error, I'd like to tackle fixing it. --- This change isâ€‚[](https://reviewable.io/reviews/servo/rust-url/466)

body: Another alternative: safelist known protocols. Perhaps manually to start (with http/https/git/mailto/ftp/smb), and then maybe through some xdg utils.

Looking at the regex which URxvt uses, I'd probably also recommend `news://`, `file://` and `www.` as valid URL starts. The only problem with this is that `www.` is not a valid URL.

The complete regex can be found here:
https://github.com/exg/rxvt-unicode/blob/0767fe71f667f5be4e8967ca6ea27e2b14c19daf/src/perl/matcher#L95

Maybe using the URL crate to verify links is not necessary? I'm sure we could try going without, otherwise we'd probably have to either prepend `http(s)://` when the potential URL starts with `www.` or just ignore `www.alacritty.io` as a valid URL.

The more I think about this, the more I like the idea of just accepting a limited amount of protocols. I think we've already got a fairly big collection in this issue, so I doubt people would run into a lot of problems. And we could always expand that when users run into problems. I'd recommend against making these a configuration option though.

rename.from: rust module paths detected as urls
rename.to: Accept only limited number of protocols for URL launching

body: Note that I just saw that even stuff like `event:` is a valid URL. Which is fair, because it is. But I don't think it should ever be accepted. So before a point release, I'd like to refine the URL clicking behavior.

Using `Url::parse` makes it easy for us to check if a a protocol is in a vec of safelisted ones with a small change [to src/term](https://github.com/jwilm/alacritty/blob/master/src/term/mod.rs#L140). Dropping the dependency on `url` to do something like `if buf.starts_with('http://') || buf.starts_with('https://') || buf.starts_with('mailto://')...` or something similar would work too, but once we start parsing parts / adding a regex I'd err on re-using the work done on url. Everything after that first line in the rxvt regex makes me feel :/

Its easy to add protocols, harder to remove. How about we start with a small number and be open to new contributions for more? Another benefit is that it would be low hanging fruit for new contributors to add more protocols. These seem like a good start:

* http
* https
* mailto
* news
* file
* git
* ssh
* ftp

Could we make the 'www.' matching discussion a separate issue? It feels like it opens a can of worms regarding `[:word:].[:tld]` matching for convenience and I'd rather be conservative for now.

@jedahan Everything you said seems sound and sane to me. I fully support taking that approach.

Adding support for `www.` could potentially be done with a heuristic (if starts with www => add http(s)), but since it's not actually a URL protocol, that seems better fit for a separate issue.

issue.title: Improve URL detection
issue.body:
Since the initial version of URL detection had some issues with being a
bit over-eager to mark things as URLs, a different approach has been
taken instead.

To make parsing easier, instead of trying to detect the URL by using a
streaming parser to the left and right of the click position, the
complete buffer is now converted to a string and then searched for
links.

With this change, it was made possible to use the `linkify` library
which handles locating the URLs in the terminal buffer text. Since it
now automatically finds all present URLs, this also brings us a step
closer to #1618.

Fixes #1903.
Fixes #1753.
Fixes #1727.

issue.title: URL detection is too liberal
issue.body:
While #1727 would help with alacritty incorrectly picking up URLs where there are none, in all cases the URL detection is too liberal. In `::` namespaced code (e.g. rust), the following line is considered to contain a URL, beginning at `iMessage::`

```rust
    â”†   let attachment = imessage::get_attachment(&self.db, request.guid)?; 
```

I believe URLs should, at minimum, be required to match `\b(?<scheme>[a-zA-Z]+:\/\/`. 

(Special leniency may be given for matching local `file:///` paths if that is desired (e.g. additionally matching `C:\foo.txt` or `/var/db/foo`) as special "local URIs", probably gated behind an option given their prevalence in terminal output.)

Unfortunately, this is probably dependent on the definition of "URI" as some RFCs (for example, RFC2806) decided to go with `scheme:address` as a URI, but I think valid cases for handling that (esp. since alacritty does not offer a per-scheme handler for URIs but rather just one catch-all handler to configure) are few and far in-between.
